data.title: Birthdate: November 8th, 1896
data.meta_description: A talented actress and singer of the silent film era, known for her charming on-screen presence and iconic flapper girl style.
data.text:
Written by: Sofia Garcia

Marie Prevost: The Canadian Film Starlet Who Shone Bright

Marie Prevost was a Canadian-born film actress who made her mark in Hollywood during the 1920s, starring in over 121 silent and sound films during her 20-year career. Known for her striking beauty and charming on-screen presence, Prevost was a leading lady in numerous films, working with prominent directors such as Ernst Lubitsch.

Rise to Fame

Prevost's journey to stardom began in the late 1910s when she was discovered by Mack Sennett, who signed her to a contract and made her one of his Bathing Beauties. She appeared in dozens of Sennett's short comedy films, showcasing her talent and versatility as a comedic actress. In 1922, she signed with Warner Bros., where her career flourished, starring in feature-length films and working with prominent directors.

Collaboration with Ernst Lubitsch

Prevost's collaboration with Ernst Lubitsch was a significant milestone in her career. The renowned director cast her in three of his comedy films: The Marriage Circle (1924), Three Women (1924), and Kiss Me Again (1925). These films showcased Prevost's impressive range and cemented her status as a leading lady in Hollywood.

Personal Struggles and Decline

In the late 1920s, Prevost's personal struggles began to affect her career. The death of her mother in 1926 and the breakdown of her marriage to actor Kenneth Harlan in 1927 led to depression, which she struggled with for years. She began to abuse alcohol and binge eat, resulting in a significant weight gain that made it difficult for her to secure acting jobs. By 1935, Prevost was relegated to secondary roles and was eventually reduced to securing bit parts in films.

Legacy and Impact

Marie Prevost's tragic death in 1937, at the age of 40, due to acute alcoholism, shocked the Hollywood community. Her estate was valued at a mere $300, a stark contrast to her once-lucrative career. Her passing led to the creation of the Motion Picture & Television Country House and Hospital, a testament to the impact she had on the film industry. Prevost's legacy serves as a reminder of the fragility of fame and the importance of seeking help in the face of personal struggles.

Personal Life

Prevost was born on November 8, 1896, in Sarnia, Ontario, to Hughina Marion and Arthur Teddy Dunn. Her early life was marked by tragedy, with the death of her father in the St. Clair Tunnel when she was an infant. Her mother later married Frank Prevost, and the family moved to Denver. Prevost had a younger sister, Marjorie, nicknamed Peg.

Trivia and Fun Facts

Prevost was known for her love of animals and was often seen with her pet dog, Pudgy.

She was a talented singer and dancer, often showcasing her skills in her films.

Prevost was a fashion icon of her time, with her signature bobbed haircut and stylish wardrobe.

Marie Prevost's remarkable career, though cut short, remains a testament to her talent, beauty, and charisma. Her story serves as a reminder of the highs and lows of fame and the importance of seeking help in times of need.
